message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Generative Agents: Interactive Simulacra of Human Behavior
Paper Abstract: Believable proxies of human behavior can empower interactive applications ranging from immersive environments to rehearsal spaces for interpersonal communication to prototyping tools. In this paper, we introduce generative agents--computational software agents that simulate believable human behavior. Generative agents wake up, cook breakfast, and head to work; artists paint, while authors write; they form opinions, notice each other, and initiate conversations; they remember and reflect on days past as they plan the next day. To enable generative agents, we describe an architecture that extends a large language model to store a complete record of the agent's experiences using natural language, synthesize those memories over time into higher-level reflections, and retrieve them dynamically to plan behavior. We instantiate generative agents to populate an interactive sandbox environment inspired by The Sims, where end users can interact with a small town of twenty five agents using natural language. In an evaluation, these generative agents produce believable individual and emergent social behaviors: for example, starting with only a single user-specified notion that one agent wants to throw a Valentine's Day party, the agents autonomously spread invitations to the party over the next two days, make new acquaintances, ask each other out on dates to the party, and coordinate to show up for the party together at the right time. We demonstrate through ablation that the components of our agent architecture--observation, planning, and reflection--each contribute critically to the believability of agent behavior. By fusing large language models with computational, interactive agents, this work introduces architectural and interaction patterns for enabling believable simulations of human behavior.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Reflection Programming - Search Results

Here's comprehensive information about reflection programming:

### Definition

Reflective programming or reflection is the ability of a process to examine, introspect, and modify its own structure and behavior.(no content)Reflection can be used for observing and modifying program execution at runtime.

### Key Capabilities

In object-oriented programming languages such as Java, reflection allows inspection of classes, interfaces, fields and methods at runtime without knowing the names of the interfaces, fields, methods at compile time. It also allows instantiation of new objects and invocation of methods.

### Common Use Cases

Reflection is often used as part of software testing, such as for the runtime creation/instantiation of mock objects. Additionally, reflection is a key strategy for metaprogramming.

### Programming Languages

Programming languages and computing platforms that typically support reflective programming include dynamically typed languages such as Smalltalk, Perl, PHP, Python, VBScript, and JavaScript. Also the .NET languages are supported and the Maude system of rewriting logic.(no content)While most languages that support reflection use runtime reflection (such as Java, Python, etc.), some use compile-time reflection, such as C++.

### Security Considerations

Reflection may allow a user to create unexpected control flow paths through an application, potentially bypassing security measures. This may be exploited by attackers. Historical vulnerabilities in Java caused by unsafe reflection allowed code retrieved from potentially untrusted remote machines to break out of the Java sandbox security mechanism.

Also the .NET languages are supported and the Maude system of rewriting logic.(no content)While most languages that support reflection use runtime reflection (such as Java, Python, etc.), some use compile-time reflection, such as C++.

### Security Considerations

Reflection may allow a user to create unexpected control flow paths through an application, potentially bypassing security measures. This may be exploited by attackers. Historical vulnerabilities in Java caused by unsafe reflection allowed code retrieved from potentially untrusted remote machines to break out of the Java sandbox security mechanism.

## Reflection Programming - Search Results

Here's comprehensive information about reflection programming:

### Definition

Reflective programming or reflection is the ability of a process to examine, introspect, and modify its own structure and behavior.(no content)Reflection can be used for observing and modifying program execution at runtime.

### Key Capabilities

In object-oriented programming languages such as Java, reflection allows inspection of classes, interfaces, fields and methods at runtime without knowing the names of the interfaces, fields, methods at compile time. It also allows instantiation of new objects and invocation of methods.

### Common Use Cases

Reflection is often used as part of software testing, such as for the runtime creation/instantiation of mock objects. Additionally, reflection is a key strategy for metaprogramming.

### Programming Languages

Programming languages and computing platforms that typically support reflective programming include dynamically typed languages such as Smalltalk, Perl, PHP, Python, VBScript, and JavaScript. Also the .NET languages are supported and the Maude system of rewriting logic.(no content)While most languages that support reflection use runtime reflection (such as Java, Python, etc.), some use compile-time reflection, such as C++.

### Security Considerations

Reflection may allow a user to create unexpected control flow paths through an application, potentially bypassing security measures. This may be exploited by attackers. Historical vulnerabilities in Java caused by unsafe reflection allowed code retrieved from potentially untrusted remote machines to break out of the Java sandbox security mechanism.

## What is Natural Language Processing?

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Key Tasks in NLP

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

## Recent Advancements

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, which laid groundwork for modern NLP. In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

I've successfully performed a web search for "Large Language Model." Here's a summary of what I found:

## What is a Large Language Model?

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.(no content)They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. These LLMs are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).(no content)As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.

## Capabilities

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

The search results also included information about specific LLMs like GPT-3, Llama, PaLM, and BERT, as well as details about their training and applications.

Links: [{"title":"Memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_architecture"},{"title":"Memory hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_hierarchy"},{"title":"Register–memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Register–memory_architecture"},{"title":"Cache-only memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cache-only_memory_architecture"},{"title":"Von Neumann architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Neumann_architecture"},{"title":"In-memory processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In-memory_processing"},{"title":"Shared-memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared-memory_architecture"},{"title":"Harvard architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_architecture"},{"title":"Uniform memory access - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_memory_access"},{"title":"Instruction set architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instruction_set_architecture"}]

I've performed the web search for "Memory architecture computer science". Here's what I found:

## Overview

Memory architecture describes the methods used to implement electronic computer data storage in a manner that is a combination of the fastest, most reliable, most durable, and least expensive way to store and retrieve information.(no content)Memory architecture also explains how binary digits are converted into electric signals and then stored in the memory cells.

## Key Memory Architectures

The earliest memory architectures are the Harvard architecture, which has two physically separate memories and data paths for program and data, and the Princeton architecture which uses a single memory and data path for both program and data storage.(no content)Most general purpose computers use a hybrid split-cache modified Harvard architecture that appears to an application program to have a pure Princeton architecture machine with gigabytes of virtual memory, but internally (for speed) it operates with an instruction cache physically separate from a data cache, more like the Harvard model.

## Memory Hierarchy

In computer architecture, the memory hierarchy separates computer storage into a hierarchy based on response time. Since response time, complexity, and capacity are related, the levels may also be distinguished by their performance and controlling technologies.

## Other Architecture Types

Uniform memory access (UMA) is a shared-memory architecture used in parallel computers. All processors in the UMA model share their physical memory uniformly.

Additionally, in-memory processing is a computer architecture in which data operations are available directly on the data memory, rather than having to be transferred to CPU registers first.

Links: [{"title":"Memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_architecture"},{"title":"Memory hierarchy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_hierarchy"},{"title":"Register–memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Register–memory_architecture"},{"title":"Cache-only memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cache-only_memory_architecture"},{"title":"Von Neumann architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Neumann_architecture"},{"title":"In-memory processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In-memory_processing"},{"title":"Shared-memory architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared-memory_architecture"},{"title":"Harvard architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_architecture"},{"title":"Uniform memory access - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_memory_access"},{"title":"Instruction set architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instruction_set_architecture"}]

I've performed the web search for "Memory architecture computer science". Here's what I found:

## Overview

Memory architecture describes the methods used to implement electronic computer data storage in a manner that is a combination of the fastest, most reliable, most durable, and least expensive way to store and retrieve information.(no content)Memory architecture also explains how binary digits are converted into electric signals and then stored in the memory cells.

## Key Memory Architectures

The earliest memory architectures are the Harvard architecture, which has two physically separate memories and data paths for program and data, and the Princeton architecture which uses a single memory and data path for both program and data storage.(no content)Most general purpose computers use a hybrid split-cache modified Harvard architecture that appears to an application program to have a pure Princeton architecture machine with gigabytes of virtual memory, but internally (for speed) it operates with an instruction cache physically separate from a data cache, more like the Harvard model.

## Memory Hierarchy

In computer architecture, the memory hierarchy separates computer storage into a hierarchy based on response time. Since response time, complexity, and capacity are related, the levels may also be distinguished by their performance and controlling technologies.

## Other Architecture Types

Uniform memory access (UMA) is a shared-memory architecture used in parallel computers. All processors in the UMA model share their physical memory uniformly.

Additionally, in-memory processing is a computer architecture in which data operations are available directly on the data memory, rather than having to be transferred to CPU registers first.

Links: [{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Graphplan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphplan"},{"title":"State-space planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_space_planning"},{"title":"Action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_selection"},{"title":"Planning Domain Definition Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Domain_Definition_Language"},{"title":"Rainier Mallol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainier_Mallol"},{"title":"Network planning and design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_planning_and_design"},{"title":"Noah Raford - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Raford"},{"title":"Yi Zeng (AI researcher) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yi_Zeng_(AI_researcher)"},{"title":"Raja Chatila - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raja_Chatila"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about planning artificial intelligence:

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## Key Concepts

**Different Approaches to Action Selection:**
Generally, artificial action selection mechanisms can be divided into several categories: symbol-based systems sometimes known as classical planning, distributed solutions, and reactive or dynamic planning.

**Classical Planning:**
Since the initial state is known unambiguously, and all actions are deterministic, the state of the world after any sequence of actions can be accurately predicted, and plans can be defined as sequences of actions, because it is always known in advance which actions will be needed.

## Planning Languages and Tools

The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence (AI) planning languages. It was first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998 mainly to make the 1998/2000 International Planning Competition (IPC) possible.(no content)Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995. Graphplan takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces, if one is possible, a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

## Practical Applications

Typical examples of domains are block-stacking, logistics, workflow management, and robot task planning.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about emergence behavior systems:

## Core Definition

An emergent behavior of a physical system is a qualitative property that can only occur in the limit that the number of microscopic constituents tends to infinity. More broadly, complex systems may exhibit behaviors that are emergent, which is to say that while the results may be sufficiently determined by the activity of the systems' basic constituents, they may have properties that can only be studied at a higher level.

## Key Characteristics

A system is "more than the sum of its parts" when it expresses synergy or emergent behavior.(no content)Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others.

## Examples

A notable example of emergence is found in nature: termites in a mound have physiology, biochemistry and biological development at one level of analysis, whereas their social behavior and mound building is a property that emerges from the collection of termites and needs to be analyzed at a different level.

## Swarm Intelligence

Emergence is particularly evident in swarm systems. The agents follow very simple rules, and although there is no centralized control structure dictating how individual agents should behave, local, and to a certain degree random, interactions between such agents lead to the emergence of "intelligent" global behavior, unknown to the individual agents.

Links: [{"title":"The Sims (video game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sims_(video_game)"},{"title":"The Sims - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sims"},{"title":"List of Sim video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Sim_video_games"},{"title":"Social simulation game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_simulation_game"},{"title":"The Sims 4 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sims_4"},{"title":"Maxis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxis"},{"title":"List of The Sims video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_The_Sims_video_games"},{"title":"The Sims 2 (Game Boy Advance video game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sims_2_(Game_Boy_Advance_video_game)"},{"title":"The Sims 3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sims_3"},{"title":"The Sims Medieval - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sims_Medieval"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about The Sims video game simulation:

## Overview

The Sims is a 2000 social simulation video game developed by Maxis and published by Electronic Arts.(no content)The franchise has sold nearly 200 million copies worldwide, and is one of the best-selling video game series of all time.

## Gameplay

The game allows players to create and control virtual people, called "Sims", and manage their daily lives in a suburban setting.(no content)The games in the Sims series are largely sandbox games, in that they lack any defined goals, and the player creates virtual people called "Sims", places them in houses, and helps direct their moods and satisfy their desires.(no content)Sims communicate in a fictional language called Simlish, which is mostly composed of blowing raspberries and saying nonsense.

## Series History

The Sims was followed by the sequels The Sims 2 (2004), The Sims 3 (2009), and The Sims 4 (2014).(no content)The Sims 4 has received over 85 million players worldwide across all platforms as of May 2024, according to EA. This includes 31 million players gained since the game went free-to-play in October 2022.

## Inspiration and Development

Game designer Will Wright was inspired to create a "virtual doll house" after losing his home during the Oakland firestorm of 1991 and subsequently rebuilding his life.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about The Sims video game simulation:

## Overview

The Sims is a 2000 social simulation video game developed by Maxis and published by Electronic Arts.(no content)The franchise has sold nearly 200 million copies worldwide, and is one of the best-selling video game series of all time.

## Gameplay

The game allows players to create and control virtual people, called "Sims", and manage their daily lives in a suburban setting.(no content)The games in the Sims series are largely sandbox games, in that they lack any defined goals, and the player creates virtual people called "Sims", places them in houses, and helps direct their moods and satisfy their desires.(no content)Sims communicate in a fictional language called Simlish, which is mostly composed of blowing raspberries and saying nonsense.

## Series History

The Sims was followed by the sequels The Sims 2 (2004), The Sims 3 (2009), and The Sims 4 (2014).(no content)The Sims 4 has received over 85 million players worldwide across all platforms as of May 2024, according to EA. This includes 31 million players gained since the game went free-to-play in October 2022.

## Inspiration and Development

Game designer Will Wright was inspired to create a "virtual doll house" after losing his home during the Oakland firestorm of 1991 and subsequently rebuilding his life.

Links: [{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"AI-assisted software development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-assisted_software_development"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_software"},{"title":"Business process automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_process_automation"},{"title":"Glossary of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Agent-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"Category:Agent-based software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Agent-based_software"}]

Here are the search results for "Software agent artificial intelligence":

## Overview

AI agents are software entities designed to perceive their environment, make decisions, and take actions autonomously to achieve specific goals. These agents can interact with users, their environment, or other agents.

## Key Characteristics

Software agents may be autonomous or work together with other agents or people.(no content)In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.(no content)Software agents interacting with people (e.g. chatbots, human-robot interaction environments) may possess human-like qualities such as natural language understanding and speech, personality or embody humanoid form.

## Modern AI Agents

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)The Information divided AI agents into seven archetypes: business-task agents, for acting within enterprise software; conversational agents, which act as chatbots for customer support; research agents, for querying and analyzing information (such as OpenAI Deep Research); analytics agents, for analyzing data to create reports; software developer or coding agents (such as Cursor); domain-specific agents, which include specific subject matter knowledge; and web browser agents (such as OpenAI Operator).

## Applications

AI-assisted software development is the use of artificial intelligence agents to augment the software development life cycle. It uses large language models (LLMs), natural language processing, and other AI technologies to assist software developers in a range of tasks from initial code generation to subsequent debugging, testing and documentation.

message_text:
## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully extracted and classified all key technologies and methodologies from the "Generative Agents: Interactive Simulacra of Human Behavior" paper. Here's a summary of what was identified:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: **Contribution** - The paper proposes a novel generative agent architecture

### Key Technologies Extracted (8 triples)

**Uses (Existing Technologies)**:
1. **Large Language Model** - Powers the agents' reasoning and behavior generation
2. **Natural Language Processing** - Processes agent experiences stored in natural language
3. **Automated Planning and Scheduling** - Enables agents to plan daily behaviors based on memories
4. **The Sims** - Inspiration for the interactive sandbox environment

**Proposes (Novel Contributions)**:
1. **Software Agent** - Introduces generative agents as a new type of agent with memory and reflection
2. **Emergence** - Demonstrates emergent social behaviors arising from individual agent actions
3. **Reflection (Computer Programming)** - Synthesizes memories into higher-level reflections
4. **Memory Architecture** - Novel memory system with observation, synthesis, and dynamic retrieval

All triples have been validated and the output file has passed quality checks. The distribution includes 2 artifacts, 2 methods, and 4 concepts, which appropriately reflects the architectural nature of the contribution.

Sources:
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
- [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing)
- [Automated planning and scheduling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling)
- [Software agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent)
- [Emergence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence)
- [The Sims](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sims_(video_game))
- [Reflection (computer programming)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflection_(computer_programming))
- [Memory architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_architecture)
